title: WCAS PHIL 260-0-20 Introduction to Moral Philosophy

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Moral philosophy is the systematic study of a range of questions, including: "What do we owe to others?" "Why should we think moral norms have authority over us?", and "What makes a person's life go best?" Over the course of the semester, students will be invited to engage directly with these questions and to evaluate which of four major moral theories?consequentialism, kantianism, contractualism, virtue ethics?offers us the most compelling way of answering them. Along the way, we will draw on real-world ethical problems?e.g. workplace conflict, sexual harassment, racism, migration, humanitarian aid, etc.?in an effort to test and critically assess the philosophical theories we study.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will:
(1) Learn how leading ethical theories ask us to think about morality.
(2) Learn how to apply these theories to concrete, real-world moral problems.
(3) Become familiar with classic criticisms of each of the major theories.
(4) Improve ability to critically evaluate and construct moral arguments.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Evaluation will based on class participation in discussion sections, a short midterm paper, and a short-answer final exam.
